raw_text:
S Korean consumers spending again
 
 South Korea looks set to sustain its revival thanks to renewed private consumption, its central bank says.
 
 The country's economy has suffered from an overhang of personal debt after its consumers' credit card spending spree. Card use fell sharply last year, but is now picking up again with a rise in spending of 14.8% year-on-year. "The economy is now heading upward rather than downward," said central bank governor Park Seung. "The worst seems to have passed." Mr Park's statement came as the bank decided to keep interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%. It had cut rates in November to help revive the economy, but rising inflation - reaching 0.7% month-on-month in January - has stopped it from cutting further. Economic growth in 2004 was about 4.7%, with the central bank predicting 4% growth this year. Other indicators are also suggesting that the country is inching back towards economic health. Exports - traditionally the driver for expansion in Asian economies - grew slower in January than at any time in 17 months. But domestic demand seems to be taking up the slack. Consumer confidence has bounced back from a four-year low in January, and retail sales were up 2.1% in December. Credit card debt is falling, with only one in 13 of the 48 million cards now in default - down from one in eight at the end of 2003. One of its biggest card issuers, LG Card, was rescued from collapse in December, having almost imploded under the weight of its customers' bad debts. The government last year tightened the rules for card lending to keep the card glut under control.
llama3.2:1b: South Korea's economy is expected to sustain its revival thanks to renewed private consumption, with credit card spending rising 14.8% year-on-year and interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%. Central bank governor Park Seung says "the worst seems to have passed" and predicts economic growth will reach 4% this year, driven by exports growing slower than expected in January but domestic demand taking up the slack.
llama3.2:3b: South Korea's economy is expected to recover thanks to increased private consumption and a decline in credit card debt. The central bank has maintained interest rates at 3.25% as inflation reaches 0.7% month-on-month, and economic growth is predicted at 4%. Consumer confidence has improved, retail sales are up 2.1%, and the number of defaulted credit cards has decreased to one in 13.
gemma2:2b: South Korea's economy is showing signs of recovery due to increased private consumption. Despite a sharp decline in credit card spending last year, it has rebounded with a significant increase this year.  Consumer confidence is rising, retail sales are up, and credit card debt levels are declining.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
South Korea is expected to experience economic growth and recovery, driven by increased spending on cards following a credit card boom.

To summarize:
- South Korea's economy is recovering.
- Credit card spending surged after previous consumers' spending spree, causing a fall in traditional credit usage but now increasing due to 14.8% year-on-year rise.
- The central bank keeps interest rates low at 3.25%, hoping to stabilize the situation and help with economic recovery.
qwen2.5:1.5b: South Korea's economy is expected to recover as private consumption resumes, with a 14.8% rise in spending from a year earlier and increased confidence among consumers driving up retail sales. Central bank rates remain low at 3.25%, despite inflation rising to 0.7%. Growth in the past year was around 4.7%, expected to continue this year as exports have slowed, while domestic demand is picking up. Credit card debt has decreased significantly from its lowest point of one in eight cards defaulting in 2003.
qwen2.5:3b: South Korea's economy is recovering thanks to increased private consumption despite lingering personal debt issues. After a sharp decline in credit card spending, usage has picked up again with a 14.8% year-on-year increase. The central bank kept interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%, having previously cut them to support economic growth but halted further reductions due to rising inflation. Other indicators show signs of improvement; exports have slowed, but domestic demand has picked up. Consumer confidence and retail sales are improving. Credit card debt is decreasing, with a lower default rate compared to the previous year. These factors suggest South Korea's economy is on an upward trajectory.
opencoder:1.5b: The Korean consumers spending again is a recovery from a period of economic panic and financial stress following a severe decline in their personal credit cards spending, which fell sharply last year due to fluctuations in consumer behavior and increased spending by others. The central bank's decision to keep interest rates at an all-time low has helped stabilize the economy and prevent it from deteriorating further.
smollm:1.7b: South Korea's economy is expected to continue growing at a moderate pace this year, driven by increased consumer spending and domestic demand. The country's central bank has been cautious in its monetary policy, keeping interest rates low to support growth. However, rising inflation - particularly food price inflation - has slowed down the economy from its previous expansionary phase. Exports have also shown signs of improvement, with sales growing at a moderate pace this year. Consumer confidence remains strong, and credit card debt is expected to continue falling as consumers become more cautious in their spending habits.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let me try to figure out how to approach this query. So, the user has provided a text about South Korea's economy and wants it summarized into just the key points without any explanations or formatting. They specified that the output should be plain text.

First, I need to read through the provided text carefully. It talks about South Korea's economy, mentioning personal debt issues due to increased credit card spending. The central bank's statement by Seung Park is crucial here because it indicates they're keeping rates low despite rising inflation. That shows economic health is a bit shaky but not entirely in despair.

The summary needs to capture the main points: continued revival with private consumption, rising spending after initial drops due to high debt, the need for rate cuts only if prices start rising, and the recovery from low consumer confidence and falling sales despite some defaults on cards. Also, mentions that LG Card was rescued and the government's efforts to manage the card glut.

I should make sure each of these points is included but in a concise manner. I'll avoid any extra details unless they're part of the core summary. The user wants only the key ideas preserved, so I have to focus on those without adding unnecessary information.
</think>

South Korea’s economy continues to recover from personal debt due to increased credit card spending, which has surged year-on-year at 14.8%. South Korea's central bank (G Koreducja) believes the economy is heading upward rather than downward, with Seung Park stating that the "worst seems to have passed." Despite rising inflation of 0.7% and a 3.25% long-term interest rate, the government has taken steps to stabilize the economy by tightening lending rules for credit cards. The central bank’s decision to keep rates low despite the economic slowdown is expected to remain until prices start rising. Key indicators include an economic growth rate of 4.7% in 2004 and projections of 4% growth this year, supported by growing domestic demand. Consumer confidence has rebounded from a four-year low, with retail sales up 2.1% in December. Despite some default rates on cards (only one in 13 out of 48 million cards), LG Card was rescued from collapse due to its customers' bad debts.
tinyllama:1.1b: South Korea looks set to sustain its economic revival due to a renewed private consumption thanks to a rise in credit card spendings and a decrease in personal debts, according to South Korean central bank Governor Park Seung. Economic growth has returned to 4% this year, following a slowdown of 1.7% in 2005. Domestic demand is taking up the slack after a four-year low in January. Consumer confidence has risen, credit card debt is falling, and one of South Korea's biggest card issuers, LG Card, was saved from collapse earlier this year, thanks to its bad debts being written off. The government's tighter rules for credit card lending are also contributing to the revival in consumer spending.
tinydolphin:1.1b: South Korea has recently seen a surge in consumer spending, as more people have been able to afford higher-priced goods and services. This growth is attributed to an increase in private credit card use, which had been on a decline before the crisis struck. The Central Bank Governor, Park Seung, reported that he believes the country's economy will start to improve once interest rates are kept at a low level.
phi:2.7b: South Korea's economy is expected to continue to improve due to a revival in private consumption and rising credit card spending. Despite concerns over personal debt, card use has picked up with a 14.8% increase year-on-year. The central bank governor believes that the worst of the economic downturn has passed and has decided to keep interest rates at an all-time low of 3.25%. Other indicators suggest that domestic demand is driving growth, such as rising consumer confidence and retail sales. Credit card debt is also falling with only one in 13 cards in default compared to one in eight at the end of last year. The government has taken steps to regulate credit lending to prevent another debt crisis.
orca-mini:3b: South Korean consumers are spending again, with renewed private consumption contributing to a revival in the economy. The central bank predicts 4% economic growth this year, and exports are growing slowly but domestic demand is taking up the slack. Consumer confidence has bounced back from a four-year low and retail sales were up 2.1% in December. However, inflation is rising to 0.7% month-on-month, stopping the central bank from cutting interest rates further. The government has also been tightening the rules for card lending to keep the card glut under control.
hermes3:3b: Korea's private consumption improving, boosting economy post-debt overhang; spending up 14.8%, interest rates held low at 3.25%.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: South Korea's central bank predicts sustained revival due to renewed private consumption, with a 14.8% increase in spending year-on-year. Despite economic growth in 2004 of 4.7%, the bank forecasts 4% growth this year, and other indicators suggest the country is returning to economic health. Export growth slowed down in January, but domestic demand is picking up as consumer confidence recovers and retail sales rise. Credit card debt is falling, with a decrease in default rates from 8.4% in 2003 to 1.7% currently.
stablelm2:1.6b: South Korea's economy is recovering due to renewed private consumption and central bank governor Park Seung says it has "the worst seems to have passed." After a drop in credit card spending, personal debt rose but is now picking up again with an 8% year-on-year increase. Interest rates remain low at 3%, having been cut twice last year to support the economy's growth of 4.7%. Exports slowed earlier this year, but domestic demand is helping recovery, as consumer confidence and retail sales improve. Credit card debt is falling, with a decrease in one in a million cards from one in eight last year.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
South Korea's economy is showing signs of recovery due to a resurgence in private consumer spending, according to the central bank. Last year, credit card usage plummeted, but it has since increased by 14.8% year-over-year, marking an upward trend in the country's economic trajectory. Central Bank Governor Park Seung affirmed that "the worst seems to have passed," and the bank maintained its interest rate at a historic low of 3.25%.

Economic growth in 2004 was approximately 4.7%, and the central bank forecasts 4% growth for this year. Domestic demand is compensating for slower export growth, as seen by a 2.1% increase in retail sales during December and a rebound in consumer confidence from its lowest level in four years. Credit card debt is decreasing, with only 8.3% of 48 million cards now in default, down from 19.5% at the end of 2003.

The government previously implemented stricter regulations on credit card lending to curb overindebtedness. One major issuer, LG Card, was saved from bankruptcy in December due to its customers' worsening debt issues. These developments suggest that South Korea is gradually mending its economic health.
chatgpt-4o-latest: South Korea's economy is recovering, driven by renewed private consumption. After a period of high personal debt from excessive credit card use, spending is rising again, up 14.8% year-on-year. Central bank governor Park Seung stated that the worst has passed, and the bank kept interest rates at a record low of 3.25% after a previous cut in November. Inflation concerns have prevented further cuts. Economic growth was 4.7% in 2004, with a 4% forecast for this year. While export growth has slowed, domestic demand is strengthening. Consumer confidence has rebounded, retail sales increased by 2.1% in December, and credit card debt is declining, with fewer defaults. LG Card was rescued from collapse, and the government has tightened lending rules to control credit card use.
reference: The country's economy has suffered from an overhang of personal debt after its consumers' credit card spending spree.The government last year tightened the rules for card lending to keep the card glut under control.Credit card debt is falling, with only one in 13 of the 48 million cards now in default - down from one in eight at the end of 2003.One of its biggest card issuers, LG Card, was rescued from collapse in December, having almost imploded under the weight of its customers' bad debts.Economic growth in 2004 was about 4.7%, with the central bank predicting 4% growth this year.Card use fell sharply last year, but is now picking up again with a rise in spending of 14.8% year-on-year.
